comments.commentBody: This is just another "Rwanda genocide" in minature.... 300 young women apparently don't count to Obama or the UN. Tho when a driver went through a check-point in front of the White House, the gov't responded. Must be Sasha and Malawa count more than 300 Nigerian girls?

At very least, I appreciate the NYT keeping this on their front pages. Please don't let up the pressure! This is a terrible situation, and the best hope for the girls is that the weight of international public opinion finally moves the government to act.

There are many mexican mangoes available in the US but the taste, texture and color is no match to Alphanso. Not sure if weather has anything to do with this. But, I know first-hand that these mangoes need very specific climate and conditions. Even small changes in temperature can ruin whole crops. The warm humid climate of western India seems to be the most suitable for these plants.

Why hasn't some enterprising capitalit brought groves of such trees here by now? Just imagine a strin of Asian markets across the country with first acess to the year's American-grown mangoes, just like the annual French wine bottled as soon as possible and rushed to market.

The priority should be on accuracy, verifiability and audit trail over convenience or expeditiousness. Electronics provide an easier means to rig votes, or at least to conceal the rigging of votes. Corrupt govts have no reason to defraud the electronic financial system - not as long as they hold the power of taxation. By contrast, when it comes to defrauding an electronic voting system, corrupt govts would certainly have a strong motivation to do so.
HOWARD DEAN!

This only matters if one believes in "with the Clinton restoration barreling toward us and stretching as far as the eye can see to President Chelsea." Otherwise, it is just a 20 year old sex scandal, between consenting adults doing things not very remarkable in themselves.

Monica was treated badly. She was also pretty foolish herself. The cheating husband caught lived down to the common stereotypes of denial and weaseling. The wronged wife may have been more unusual in her reactions to these events, but we still don't know much about that, none of it here. No story now, twenty years later.

Unless the Clinton restoration is barreling toward us and stretching as far as the eye can see to President Chelsea. But I don't think so. Hillary has many other things to overcome, such as all the things that caused her to lose to Obama. We are if anything even less willing to tolerate a Democratic version of a neo-con on wars, who also pushed and still wants to push trade deals at our expense, and failed at a far worse health plan.

It is still three years to the election. A lot can happen. Not much is likely to improve things for Hillary in that time.

So PLEASE will a real Democrat step up and run for President?
But the French don't want her back.
Then why bother to comment on such an uninteresting column?
You need to go back to Paris. At least those columns were interesting.

It's been my ongoing impression that natural gas burns much cleaner than coal, yet you state that scientists agree it doesn't. On the EPA website, they sya the following"
"The average emissions rates in the United States from natural gas-fired generation are: 1135 lbs/MWh of carbon dioxide, 0.1 lbs/MWh of sulfur dioxide, and 1.7 lbs/MWh of nitrogen oxides.1 Compared to the average air emissions from coal-fired generation, natural gas produces half as much carbon dioxide, less than a third as much nitrogen oxides, and one percent as much sulfur oxides at the power plant.2 In addition, the process of extraction, treatment, and transport of the natural gas to the power plant generates additional emissions." Then they go on about using "combined cycle technology" in turbines to increase efficiency further.
So, who am I to believe?

If nuclear IS more expensive, it's based on fear not facts. Most rational studies show nuclear (even after shut down and clean up) to be 2 to 4 times cheaper than your preferred energy sources. Fukushima is hardly an unavoidable model, there are reactor designs and systems that could be used as safely statistically as any other energy provider. The real question is how much more do you think we can afford to spend on energy before it does a very different, but just as serious damage to America as the one you fear.

@Larry, here are some of my sources on thorium and nuclear power. I haven't saved all of them, so you'll have to forgive me for the short list.:

Vice Magazine's documentary "The Thorium Dream", including interviews with one of the original engineers of light water reactors: http://www.vice.com/motherboard/thorium-dream

Wikipedia (sources within article confirmed): http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thorium-based_nuclear_power

Forbes: http://www.forbes.com/sites/energysource/2012/02/16/the-thing-about-thor...

On dangers of different forms of energy including coal, deaths per terawatt hour: http://nextbigfuture.com/2011/03/deaths-per-twh-by-energy-source.html

We need to be practical. We don't have the resources yet to rely on solar and wind, but thorium reactors are very doable. China, India, and the US are among the countries researching and implementing this technology. Most of the cons are short term monetary issues, including research funding, but it is cheaper in the long run.

Mr. Huntsman, I was packing my bags and getting ready to move to Utah to vote for you in your next election until you got to the part about having an open discussion about nuclear and gas powered electricity.

There is no debate within serious scientific circles about the emissions consequences of natural gas, which are as bad as coal, and possibly worse. NOAA has looked at this in detail.

If the alternative view for purposes of discussion is the Texas study of cherry picked gas wells, you're smart man, Jon, go all the way here, and ask a scientist about that study's methodology. A freshman statistics class is all you need to know here.

Natural gas is also quite finite, while permanently poisoning watersheds all over the country, especially in the Rocky Mountain states. The NOAA report makes the coal emissions parity clear, and Fox has shown up close what it's like to live in the middle of fracking.

Nuclear, of course, was dead even before Fukushima. It's a classic government boondoggle, with taxpayer loan guarantees and melddown insurance. Nuclear is done, and both solar and wind are already cheaper.

Do you really want to click with the millennials? Try going all the way with the truth about these four technologies. They will fall off their chairs, and sprint to the voting booth. Even if you are still a Republican.
So how many million cars are there in the United States? See the problem?

While the Republicans were working to impeach Clinton, doing everything they could to distract him from his job, he was working to take down Osama Bin Laden (according to Richard Clark).

We saw the consequences of the GOP's lack of seriousness on 9/11, when America's president was an immature, incompetent frat boy who had to be told to stop reading "The Pet Goat."
Rita; pls write more - great points.
Seems to me Bill Clinton signed the bill decimating Glass-Steagall for his buddy Andy Weil of Travelers.

Maybe if the Republicans had spent more time debating the wisdom of repealing the Glass-Steagall Act and less time on impeaching Pres. Clinton for attempting to hide his peccadillo with Ms. Lewinsky, they might have prevented the Great Recession and the loss of thousands of jobs. (O.K. That's a stretch - if the Republicans had actually concentrated on policy, they would have sold us down the river to Wall Street a lot faster.)

Ms. Lewinsky serves to remind us that politics has trumped policy for the last 20 years with only a very brief respite from politics in the aftermath of 9/11.

She needs to continue her therapy in private. We are not part of it. Nor is Hillary Clinton. End of story. Now on to the latest Republican strategy for avoiding their jobs: Benghazi.
Yes, Maureen, please move on and skip the drink with Monica. Quit being such a lightweight.

Nope, She doesnt.

The "THAT WOMAN" incident showed the natural dishonesty of the Clintons. Of course he should not have been impeached for an affair, nor cornered into lying about it. BUt it does reveal what piece of work he is, and for that matter Hilary.

Monica just found him attractive. I found him attractive. So what.

She did nothing wrong poor lamb.

I hope she makes a tiny bit of money off it.
Both of you need to move on.

K-S, for a Var. on a theme, look on page nine. Actually, that might be 'page nino'.

Interesting about NOMAR. Do you know where the pair of cigars came from?

his first name is anthony. his last name is a combination of his father's (garcia) and his mother's (parra). his middle name, nomar, is indeed his father's name backwards---it's ramon, though, not roman.
th-th-that's all, folks!

lol, who knew?

Milo turned out even cuter than ever. As for the newbie, hard to say, but seems to have a lot of potential.

Mazel tov!

Haven't seen a "Var." clue in a while. Can't remember ever seeing a Var. on a theme.

If memory serves, NOMAR Garicaparra's first name came from reversing his father's, Roman.
You doing a Butkus on this guy?

The kicker about nuclear, even if you embrace the latest technology (which I would if they were fully recyclable), which is not being funded or developed, is that infrastructure is being degraded, and the wastes are going to be a serious problem. Instead we are "grandfathering" facilities that are past their useful life.

Two week power outages are becoming much more common these days. Infrastructure is not being funded. What are people thinking? Are they thinking?
How do you put something behind you by putting it front and center?

Considering the number of people who regarded Barack Obama as some kind of messiah during the 2008 presidential election cycle, I'd say he was once more charismatic and inspirational than Bill Clinton ever was.

This column is timely, with Mrs. Clinton not so secretly looking toward that seat in the White House in the very near future. Hillary certainly isn't Bill, she's far more focused than he, the man who dreamt he really could have it all, a secret affair with Monica while wielding his influence as world leader.

Part of me likes the Clintons, Bill is likely the most inspirational and charismatic speaker of our generation. But there is that part of the power couple that shows their lust for raw power and influence, a couple who would do almost anything, including defaming a young woman whose only real ‘crime’ was to become enraptured by Bill's charms.

I agree with Monica that the relationship was consensual, but Bill did have all of those years, sexual and otherwise. He was a very experienced man. It's understandable that she wants to clear the air, though the timing of her latest revelations is 'interesting'. Who can blame her for wanting to get back at them a bit, and she’s right, it is time for her to put it all behind her.
Education is not something they value. Period.

Uh... yah. So if I break into your house (hypothetically) and steal something really really valuable (hypothetically).... it's not a crime unless I'm convicted??

Get a grip on reality.
No, Joey, you are not a criminal until you are convicted.

So, neither Al Capone nor O.J. Simpson are criminals?

Semantically, either one has immigrated to the country legally or illegally. It is a binary situation; if an immigrant is not in the former category, having met the legal requirements for immigration, then one is in the second category, an illegal immigrant.

One is not a felon unless convicted, but anyone who commits an illegal act is still a criminal.

I am glad that Justice Sotomayor has used the term "undocumented immigrant" rather than the term "illegal immirgant".

Unless someone has been charged and convicted of illegally entering the country, they are not illegal. They are undocumented in that the country has no record of them entering or residing in the country.
Legal illiteracy, eh? I'll take your referenced opinion by Sotomayor and raise you Bush v. Gore and Citizens United. "Legal illiteracy" is in the eye of the beholder.

It is highly unlikely that Col Putin would ever think "that he can control the separatist forces he’s unleashed in eastern Ukraine and dial them up or down as he pleases." That is contrary to all Russian theory.

They have long believed that once committed, forces run onward by their own logic. For example, their military units are organized into more but smaller units, because they feel that a commander can only commit a unit. It just goes. Decisions are go/no go. Col Putin was trained in these assumptions, and he has used his military that way.

Putin makes go/no go decisions, not attempts to fine tune the actions of forces in motion like LBJ deciding bombing targets, ordnance, and even flight paths in the White House.

Putin may well know his adversaries better than they know themselves. Self knowledge is not a strong point of any of our politicians.

This is also wrong about energy policy. The suggestions for export of gas to Europe are designed to serve that industry, not our foreign policy goals. They will be too late to matter in current events, delivering the first gas years after this is over.

All they can do is raise US gas prices, get more for our energy companies as they tie our prices to the highest of the world market by spending hundreds of billions of our money on infrastructure to tie us into the highest priced parts of that world market.

Friedman consistently pushes higher prices for oil and gas. He consistently fails to see the down sides of that.
Send in a team of unidentified assets and let them do their thing.  Kill them all.....

I can think of no more appropriate venue for the use of Western Liberal Democracy's considerable military and intelligence capabilities than in crushing the vile group that calls itself Boko Haram.

We need to empower women all over the world to obtain western education and protect and support them when they do!

Western education is no forbidden, It is the Future!
Western Educated Women will consign misogyny and its superstitions masquerading as so called religion to the dust bin of history.
Finally!! And Godspeed.
The Climate is changing?  No way!  Why didn't anyone say something.....?....
I strongly agree.  Many of us grew up in the midwest on meat & potatoes, milk, and coke and candy bars.  My diet (along with 'comfort foods) has completely changed - for the better.

I disagree that childhood habits (esp. from the new "invented" foods) lock you in "forever".

I grew up in the 1960s, by preference eating only hamburgers, fries, and deepdish pizza. Upon moving to Europe - and marriage to a veggie lover helped - I became a slow food devotee. I might eat my old favorites once or twice a year, by circumstance rather than craving. It helps that fast food (indeed any food) in France is not cheap, but more important is the life style we have chosen.

In my experience, it depends a great deal on what is available in your environment, what it costs, and what you believe in.
Become? This has been going on forever. Women and children have always been spoils of war.

Clean air ...??? for generations to come...???? ...well..
if Obama had any real guts...he would try to ban...
monster vehicles....and any kind of excess of burning Co
but he doesn't do anything but SMILE the OBAMA smile..
now...that is not solving our climate change...just smiling.

So....the next candidate/s must be resolved to act on a realistic ban on carbon emissions.. .and a..ban the use of coal...and
go solar...and wind...I have yet to see or hear Barak Obama promote CLEAN and GREEN...nope ...not once.
Obama ....is just becoming an ineffective echo...so let
us look forward to someone else in the White House..now

Thank you!  Actually, I think Americans are getting accustomed to the price of gas ~$3.80 or so.  I remember the outrage after Katrina when the price of gas was briefly $4.50.  Smaller cars started showing up more, people drove slower - trying to conserve fuel and money.  Now, everyone is back to their former speeds driving pickups and huge SUV's.  Despite the fact it would hurt me personally (long commute, no public transit, but a very efficient car), I think the gas tax should be increased by a dollar - use the added revenue for improved infrastructure (failing bridges anyone?) which would also create jobs.
Good point, why is there never anything in the back of a pick-up? My brother-in-law has a farm and doesn't have a pick-up because they are too expensive to run. He rents one if he needs one.

Love the idea, Mr. Friedman, just one problem.

F150 is the # 1 selling vehicle in America, followed by Chevy Silverado and Dodge Ram pickups. The first car shows up in #4. Who knew there were so many workers who needed pickups? And why is there never anything in the back? American exceptionalism, don't see that anywhere else in the world.

Every day in my quiet, safe cul de sac neighborhood, a whole fleet of 2 ton SUVs fire up, drive about 4 or 5 houses down the block, idle for 10 minutes or so, disgorge one tiny child each for the school bus and motor back home.

And then there is the other half of America, driving comfortable, fuel efficient cars to work, walking their kids to the bus and in more fortunate communities, jumping on a train to cross town.

Half of the US is spending many thousands a year for gas and payments on monster vehicles, often adding to debt and stealing from the future. That half has apoplexy every time Fox News announces that Obama is raising gas prices again.

And that half is a potent electoral force because they drive those big machines to polling places and vote reliably against anyone who proposes a new tax, especially on freedom fuel.

Wow - that is a very unscientific response on a matter of science. No one is saying the climate has not changed in the past, what science is saying is the reason for the change now and the rate of change is different.
